BC-GUNS-AZR 
PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS, VOT ERS DUEL OVER GUN ISSUE 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By JEFF BARKER  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   WASHINGTON _ Presidential candidates, like calculating poker
players, once believed they had more to lose than gain by
mentioning guns.

   But a rash of shootings by teenagers and young adults has some
in the 2000 campaign gambling that the time is right to speak out
about gun control.

   Even those candidates who seek little or no change in the law
are finding their gun-control positions more scrutinized than ever
before.

   While voters often complain there is little distinction between
the political parties, gun control is an issue in which the lines
couldn't be more defined: The Democrats want to dramatically
strengthen gun laws, while the Republicans favor modest controls.

   ``This is about as clear as it gets,'' said Allan J. Lichtman,
chairman of the history department at American University. ``There
really are quite sharply chiseled differences between the
parties.''

   As the candidates campaign for the primaries in early 2000,
voters will find there also are differences within the parties
themselves.

   Among Republicans, Elizabeth Dole broke ranks early in May by
endorsing mandatory child-safety locks for handguns. Sen. John
McCain, R-Ariz., also favors mandatory locks, but former Vice
President Dan Quayle does not. Neither does Texas Gov. George W.
Bush, the GOP front-runner.

   Instead, Bush ``has supported voluntary efforts of gun
manufacturers for child-safety locks,'' Bush spokeswoman Mindy
Tucker said. Some gunmakers have voluntarily agreed to
automatically sell a safety device with every handgun, but many
have not.

   In contrast to his Democratic rivals, Bush has not proposed any
new federal gun controls. ``What he wants to focus on is
prosecuting the criminals who commit the crimes with the guns,''
Tucker said.

   Bush does support instant background checks on gun purchasers at
gun and ammunition shows, something that already is required of the
licensed dealers at those events. The idea behind instant checks is
to ensure that gun-show customers around the nation are screened
even if they buy from unlicensed vendors.

   But gun-control advocates say the instant-check proposal falls
short because it realistically can take a few days for the FBI to
determine whether buyers have criminal or mental-health records
that would disqualify them from buying a gun.

   Arizona is among 14 states in which officials conduct background
checks by linking directly to FBI computers. In most other states,
the FBI conducts the checks, or the checks are made with a
combination of state and FBI resources.

   Democrats, accusing Bush of undue caution, believe they can
capitalize on the issue if Bush wins the Republican nomination.

   But Frank Luntz, a well-known Republican pollster based in
suburban Washington, disagrees. He said Americans are concerned
about school violence, but that they don't believe gun control is
necessarily the answer, especially not when presented with other
approaches.

   ``Yes, they (the Democrats) will score in New York, and they may
score in San Francisco. But in the rest of the country, gun control
is the least-best option for most Americans,'' Luntz said.

   ``If the option is only gun control or nothing, the public will
overwhelmingly choose gun control. But if this is put in the
context of other components in society _ whether it be Hollywood
and television, violence in video games, even criminal elements
such as stricter sentencing, tougher laws _ they will choose those
options over gun control,'' Luntz said.

   The two Democratic candidates, Vice President Al Gore and former
New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley, have both called for mandatory
registration of handguns and a ban on cheap ``junk guns'' that are
easy to buy and conceal.

   Their proposals go way too far for GOP candidates. None of the
Republicans favors registration of new handguns.

   ``We're absolutely opposed,'' said Jonathan Baron, a spokesman
for Quayle. ``The Second Amendment (right to bear arms) clearly and
unarguably does not permit, in his view, the registration of
handguns.''

   The Democrats' aggressive stance represents an historic change.
For years, candidates of both parties were afraid of touching the
issue for fear of alienating either rural, pro-gun voters on one
side, or urban, gun-control advocates on the other.

   Arizona, in particular, has long been regarded as a strong
gun-rights state. Most of the state's GOP federal officeholders
have sided with gun manufacturers in rejecting most gun-control
proposals.

   Following an emotional gun-control debate in Congress last
month, Rep. Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz., issued a statement detailing the
delicate balancing act that the issue often presents.

   During the debate, Kolbe favored a 24-hour waiting period _ but
no longer _ to conduct background checks on gun-show purchasers.

   ``I believe in the civilian's right to bear arms and I believe
in a legitimate government role in assuring public safety,'' Kolbe
said. ``These are not mutually exclusive. They appear to clash and
conflict, but they also converge. I have been both enthused and
exasperated at trying, with others, to create the proper
equilibrium.''

   This year, Democrats are gambling that the string of school
shootings _ from West Paducah, Ken., to Littleton, Colo. _ has
altered the political climate.

   In particular, the April rampage by two Columbine High School
students in Littleton that left 13 innocent victims dead has helped
make the issue more politically potent, especially among women
voters.

   Providing the issue with a face, more than 80 high school
students from Littleton and the Denver area appeared Thursday with
President Clinton to endorse gun-law reforms, including
child-safety locks and gun-show background checks.

   ``We're a diverse group who do not agree on everything, but we
do agree that our gun laws are not working and must be changed,''
said David Winkler, a recent graduate of a Denver high school.
``While Columbine was overwhelming, tragedies of a smaller scale
take place every day.''

   Bradley, the underdog for the Democratic nomination, believes
there now is ``an opportunity to do something the public wants and
really needs leadership on,'' said Eric Hauser, his spokesman.

   ``The attitudes on gun control, whether you're looking at
polling or anecdotes, show that there is a yearning to reduce gun
violence,'' Hauser said.

   Political scientists say the school shootings have accelerated
the gun-control debate. If there is indeed a window for gun
control, the academicians don't know how long it will last.

   ``I don't think the country has ever seen anything in its entire
history like this rash of school shootings,'' American University's
Lichtman said. ``And the American public does tend to be aroused by
the spectacular, flashy or, in this case, horribly tragic events.
They give prominence to issues that were not nearly as prominent
prior to that.''

   But Jack Nagel, a University of Pennsylvania political
scientist, said the election year is still months away _ quite a
long time in politics for an issue to endure.

   ``I think it depends mainly on what else competes with it (gun
control),'' Nagel said.

   ``Gun control seems to be analogous to abortion in that it's
something that a minority of people feel passionate about. Most
people, although they care about it, usually don't rank it that
high in their priorities. But if the economy continues not to be a
worry and if there is no big foreign policy problem, then their
attention might shift to this, especially because of Columbine,''
Nagel said.

   Many of the Republican candidates are still cautious about the
subject to the point of sounding skittish.

   Dole, for example, won't use the expression ``gun control.'' It
is, in effect, banned from her vocabulary.

   ``She doesn't view it that way (as gun control),'' said her
spokesman, Ari Fleischer. ``She calls it `crime control' and `gun
safety.'''
